summary: This document is an FBI interview summary (302 form) with Michael Turnball, a security contractor hired for Little St. James and Great St. James islands in July 2019. It details his hiring, duties, restrictions, and observations about the limited access and personnel on the islands after Jeffrey Epstein's death.

persons.name: Michael Turnball
persons.role: Security Contractor / Owner of MT Security
persons.context: Interviewed by the FBI regarding his security work on Little St. James and Great St. James islands, which he started on July 31, 2019. He was hired by Daphne Wallace and reported to property manager Anna Rodriguez.

persons.name: Daphne Wallace
persons.context: Hired Michael Turnball for security work on Little St. James island, having obtained his number from someone else.

persons.name: Anna Rodriguez
persons.context: The property manager for Little St. James island whom Michael Turnball met with regarding his security duties.

connections.description: Wallace hired Turnball to provide security services for Little St. James island.
Rodriguez, as property manager, was Turnball's point of contact and supervisor regarding his duties on the island.
Turnball reported that the only people he saw on the islands were staff, attorneys, maintenance workers, and boat captains, indicating his limited interaction with them.

events.title: Michael Turnball Begins Security Work
events.description: Michael Turnball started working security on Little St. James island, hired to patrol beaches and look for unauthorized visitors, including paparazzi.

keyFacts: Security was hired for Little St. James and Great St. James islands starting July 31, 2019, after Jeffrey Epstein's death, specifically to look for paparazzi and unauthorized visitors.
Michael Turnball, the security contractor, was restricted from entering any structures on the islands and was only allowed to patrol the beaches and use the staff bathroom.
Turnball was required to sign a non-disclosure agreement as part of his employment for the islands.
The only people Turnball observed on the islands were staff, attorneys, maintenance workers, and boat captains, with no interaction with other workers.
Turnball's company, MT Security, employed seven people for security duties on both Little St. James and Great St. James.
